data.title: Uninstalling an extension w/ dependencies should also offer to uninstall those dependencies
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12658

Ideally # of installs is directly proportional to # of uninstalls. Right now, if an extension pack installs several dependencies, you have to go through, find, and uninstall every single one. It's like maple syrup. You get just a little bit on your hand and then somehow it defies the laws of physics, multiplies, and it's everywhere!

Extensions shouldn't be like maple syrup. ðŸ˜œ

data.title: Closing integerated terminal after stopping launched debug session prevents further launching.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0-insider (c94c824db64a88bd4909da2e84e44316dbf8e8fb)
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.15

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch a debug session in the integrated terminal using `runInTerminalRequest`.
2. Stop the session using the red stop button.
3. Close the terminal in which the debugged program was launched.
4. Launch another debug session.

Expected response: Debugger starts another terminal with the debugged program
Observed response: Error message => 

> Terminal with ID 1 does not exist (has it already been disposed?). Stopping the debug adapter.

data.title: Installing an extension pack should also list other dependencies it intends to install
data.body:
Testing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12658

Right now a popup appears asking if I want to install dependencies of the extension pack, which of course begs the question... "what are the dependencies?" More visibility into this would be helpful. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/18936227/8ecba7e6-859a-11e6-92eb-52e97fd08a28.png)

data.title: HTML mode produces non-normalized links
data.body:
**Updated findings:**
The HTML mode produces non-normalized URIs when they have leading dots. The mode should ensure that the paths used for producing URIs are always normalized so that any "." and ".." are removed from the path and normalized.

While testing #12896:
- Explorer highlights wrong item.
- Two Tabs would open for the file created.

![12953](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/18935440/f6db6dc2-8594-11e6-943f-992ab1e70033.gif)

data.title: Support Drag and Dropping From OSX Emoji and Symbols Panel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 Insiders
- OS Version: OSX 10.11

Using the OSX Emoji & Symbol panel, some applications support dragging and dropping symbols directly from the panel into a text field insert them. Apps that with support this behavior include: TextMate, Text Edit, Safari, and Chrome.

![sep-28-2016 15-51-23](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18935306/fab20cd6-8593-11e6-99dc-e100191a115a.gif)

data.title: Hovering over argument with same name as outer variable produces nothing
Breakpoints not resolving properly in attach configuration on Windows
Cannot Double Click To Insert Emoji Using OSX Emoji Panel ðŸ˜ž
data.body:
VSCode 1.6 Insiders
OSX 10.11
##### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open blank text document with UTF-8 encoding.
2. Open the emoji panel 
3. Double click on one to insert it into current document
##### Expected

Emoji inserted into file
##### Actual

Two characters are inserted and rendered as missing symbols:

![sep-28-2016 15-46-13](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18935111/b44456d8-8592-11e6-92ab-91f97acede37.gif)

This seems to be a regression since 1.5. Could be related to the electron 1.3 upgrade?

data.title: QuickFix selection reset
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider (c94c824db64a88bd4909da2e84e44316dbf8e8fb, 2016-09-28T06:05:08.351Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Found verifying #12531

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add compile error in C#
2. Before or right after the squiggles are shown open QuickFix with the keyboard shortcut
3. Quickly move the selection down a few entries in the list of QuickFixes
4. Wait and observe: The selection goes away

Not a regression because in 1.5.3 the drop-down closed instead.

data.title: Markdown No Colorization of Block Quote Punctuator When Indented
data.body:
For markdown file: ``` > start
bold text
> second **line** . > start
bold text
> second **line** . >
bold text
> second **line** . >
bold text
> second **line** ``` All these are rendered the same and should be highlighted the same. However, the `>` is not highlighted if it is indented at all. ![screen shot 2016-09-28 at 3 20 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18934550/33618d36-858f-11e6-8743-75a5e6aeb1ba.png) Up to three spaces indent should be supported on the first line of the block quote, and any number of spaces on the next lines.

data.title: With tabs disabled, dirty indicator doesn't change to Close X on hover.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.6.0 insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

When Tabs are disabled, the dirty indicator was moved to cover the Close button at the right side of the editor group title bar. 
Should hover display the Close button "x"? The tooltip ("Close") is displayed but the dirty indicator circle remains.
This is not consistent with OPEN EDITORS and when Tabs are enabled where hover shows the Close "x"

data.title: Incorrect Markdown Colorizaiton for Block Element on Line Immediatly After a Paragraph
data.body:
For a markdown file like this: `````` text text text 1. list 2. list . text text text
**html**
. text text text ```js var code = code; ``` `````` The numbered list, html block, and fenced code block elements following the line are nor properly colorized. They are rendered properly in the preview. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18934111/e025d566-858c-11e6-85df-557fde95dfb1.png) In the case of the html, the `**html**` text should not be colorized since it is html content, not markdown. Adding a blank line after the paragraph fixes the colorization. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18934233/859bc3fc-858d-11e6-81a0-660495cd0a6d.png)

data.title: --locale cmd line argument not working (Windows)
data.body:
Testing #12519 

From the command line, `code-insiders --locale zh-TW` doesn't bring up the correct locale (always English)

data.title: Add Space After Default Extension Queries
data.body:
Adds a space after the default extension search queries so that users can start typing a query term right away. See Issue #12924 for details

Closes #12924

data.title: Help > Release Notes still goes to website
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.6.0 insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10

Should Help > Release Notes also display the release notes in product?

data.title: Inconsistent Behavior When Using 'Toggle Word Wrap' and 'editor.wrappingColumn'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 Insiders
- OS Version:
##### Steps to Reproduce
1. Add `"editor.wrappingColumn": 40` and `"editor.wordWrap": true` user settings. 
2. Open a document with a long long.
3. Toggle Word wrap (should disable word wrap)
4. Toggle word wrap again.
##### Expected

Text wraps back to the 40 column mark.
##### Actual

Text wraps to the editor frame boundaries instead.

![sep-28-2016 10-28-18](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12821956/18932451/4e3cf8ac-8585-11e6-9bf7-955b53653243.gif)

I'd expect the text in this case to render the same as it does with  `"editor.wrappingColumn": 40` and `"editor.wordWrap": true` applies. Changing the `wrappingColumn` setting causes it to render properly.

data.title: Implement an overflow design for the status bar
data.body:
Testing #12519 

Change window.zoomLevel in settings to 3, and shrink the window a bit until the "responsive" design starts kicking in. Pressing Ctrl+M then toggles the UI between the following two states:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/18932111/d3f702dc-8583-11e6-833f-42df3a6fbdd0.png)

This is problematic because
-  there's no indication to the user what just happened or that the mode switch was successful.
- It's unclear (from a user perspective) why stuff just disappeared from the status bar

data.title: Console/Output don't maintain their scroll position when hide/show panel, terminal does
data.body:
- Have some output in the Debug Console or Output pane.
- Scroll up
- Hide the panel
- Show the panel
- Now they are scrolled all the way down

That might be ok, but if you repeat the same steps for the terminal, it maintains its scroll position across show/hide. I like that behavior better. Either way, I think it should be consistent.

data.title: Hang on Workspace Recommended Extension Search with Too Many Recommended Extensions in extensions.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6 Insiders
##### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a `.vscode/extensions.json` file
2. Add `"a.a"` to the `"recommendations"`.
3. Really recommend `"a.a"` by repeating it **one hundred thousand** times.
4. Try searching workspace recommended extensions
##### Result

Hang. Window no longer responds for a minute or two before getting search results back.
##### Expected

There would seem to be few valid cases for having more than 1000 recommended extensions or so in a workspace. Maybe we should generate a warning and reduce the query to that size if it is too large. In any case, this should not hang the UI.

data.title: Help > Accessibility Options context menu should be hidden
data.body:
Testing #12519

We handle accessibility in our own way, so having the additional menu item from chromium is confusing. Not to mention, the resulting dialog itself is inaccessible (not resizeable, confusing icons, etc.) 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/762848/18929790/c4173098-857a-11e6-8c42-16edb8d1b929.png)

Related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12928

data.title: 500 Error on Workspace Recommended Extension Search with Invalid extensions.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders 1.6
##### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create a blank `.vscode/extensions.json`
2. Edit the file like so:

``` json
{
    "recommendations": [
        "a"
    ]
}
```

Go to Extensions and search `@recommended:workspace`.
##### Expected

No search results are returned or some more helpful error message is shown.
##### Actual

A 500 is returned by the server and shown as an error in the UI. It seems the extension names needs a `.` in it.

Other fun cases that return 500s:

```
"recommendations": [
        ""
    ]
```

This one at least generates a warning in the workspace:

```
"recommendations": [
        null
    ]
```

returns a 400 instead, along with workspace warning:

```
"recommendations": [
        {"key": "value"}
    ]
```

data.title: Enter key non-functional
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.3 (5be4091987a98e3870d89d630eb87be6d9bafd27, 2016-09-22T08:50:42.185Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14937

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a current or new file, doesn't matter what file type it is.
2. Press enter, hold and press enter, press enter a thousand times in a row, toggle "Insert" button, no response. This applies to the main enter key and the one on the number pad.

Enter key works in all other programs. All other keys work in VS Code. I'm on a desktop PC w/ a Bluetooth keyboard.
